subject: Breakfast — Not Included (OTA Booking)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Thank you for your email.

We get questions about complimentary breakfast from time to time, and we're happy to explain the logic clearly.

### 1) What breakfast is

Complimentary breakfast is a **direct-booking benefit** that we include only for reservations made through **our own website**.

### 2) Why it's not included on third-party reservations

When a reservation is made through a third-party booking platform, that platform charges a **commission** for providing discovery, marketing, booking and payment infrastructure. This means we receive less for the same room and dates than we do when you book directly with us.

To keep pricing consistent and avoid penalising guests on platforms with noticeably higher listed rates, we apply a simple and transparent approach:

* **Direct booking (our website):** we include breakfast as a thank-you for booking directly.
* **Third-party booking:** breakfast is not included because part of the rate is effectively covering the platform's commission and services.

### 3) What guests *do* get when booking via a third party

Third-party platforms aren't "worse" — they deliver value in a different way. Guests who book through them typically benefit from things like:

* **easy comparison** of properties, locations and prices in one place
* **reviews and ratings** that help with decision-making
* **multi-language / multi-currency** booking and payment
* **centralised customer support** and reservation management
* sometimes **loyalty rewards**, credits, or platform-specific promotions

In short: with a platform booking, part of what you pay supports the platform services you chose to use. With a direct booking, we can put that same value into an on-property benefit such as breakfast.

### 4) Equivalent examples in other industries (same principle)

This "channel benefit" approach is common elsewhere:

* **Airlines:** booking direct often includes added flexibility, easier changes, bonus points, or seat selection; third-party fares can be cheaper or easier to compare, but may have fewer included perks or more restrictions.
* **Car rental:** direct bookings sometimes include an upgrade, additional driver, or more flexible amendments; aggregator sites offer comparison and sometimes coupons, but the rental company typically receives less after fees.
* **Events / theatres:** buying from the venue can include better support and fewer add-on fees; ticket marketplaces bundle convenience, discovery, and their own service fees.
* **Retail brands:** many brands offer "direct purchase" benefits (free shipping, free returns, gift wrapping, or loyalty points) that are not available when purchasing the same product through a marketplace that charges seller fees.

It's the same underlying trade-off: **marketplace convenience and infrastructure vs. direct-booking benefits from the provider**.

### 5) What this means for your reservation

Because your reservation was made through a third-party booking platform, **breakfast is not included** in your rate.

If you would like breakfast during your stay, you are very welcome to add it on-site — just let us know and reception will explain the options.

For future stays, booking directly through our website ensures you receive all direct-booking benefits, including breakfast. Details are here:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/assistance/booking-basics>

{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Thank you for your question about parking.

As is common in central Positano, Hostel Brikette doesn't have private on-site parking, and we're not able to reserve parking spaces in local garages on a guest's behalf.

Parking in Positano is very limited and can be expensive: paid garages near the pedestrian centre commonly charge around €8–€10 per hour, and metered street parking (when you can find it) is typically around €3 per hour.

To give some context on how scarce space is in this area, private garages on the Amalfi Coast can sell for six-figure sums (you'll sometimes see listings around €140k–€250k+).

Some options guests commonly use:

Paid garages near the town centre (for example around Piazza dei Mulini / Via Cristoforo Colombo) — these are first-come, first-served and can fill quickly in summer.

Free parking (treat as luck, not a plan): In practice, free spots in and around Positano are not something you can plan around. Some drivers sometimes find pull-outs or unmarked spaces, but rules change and fines are common. If you want to try your luck, do it only if you can also afford the backup plan (a paid garage). One location sometimes mentioned by drivers is Plus Code JFJG+2X Positano, SA — please treat this as a "maybe," not a promise. Always check local signage and never block traffic or driveways.

Arriving without a car (ferry, bus, taxi/private transfer) — many guests choose this option to avoid the parking challenge entirely.

For full details on parking, ZTL rules, and arrival options: <https://hostel-positano.com/en/assistance/arriving-by-car>

subject: Getting to Spiaggia Grande — Walk or Bus
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Spiaggia Grande (Positano's main beach) is about 15–25 minutes from the hostel, depending on how you go.

*Walk down*
Follow the staircase route from the hostel via Viale Pasitea — quicker than Google Maps suggests, with great views on the way. Allow 20 minutes, wear sturdy sandals, and carry water as there are no shops until you reach the promenade.

*Take the orange Interno bus*
The bus stop is about 100 m from the hostel (turn left out of the front door, past Bar Internazionale). Board the orange Interno Positano bus towards Positano centre and get off at Piazza dei Mulini — the beach is a 3–4 minute walk from there. subject: Spiaggia Grande — Where to Sit (Free Zones and Clubs)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Spiaggia Grande has four distinct zones — knowing which is which saves confusion on arrival.

*Zone 1 — Free public beach*
The widest section in the centre. Arrive before 10:00 in high season to get a spot near the waterline. The pebbles heat up quickly — bring a thick mat or towel and water shoes.

*Zone 2 — Residents' strip*
A fenced area reserved for Positano residents. Lifeguards check wristbands; visitors should stick to Zone 1 or the paid clubs.

*Zone 3 — L'Incanto beach club*
Orange loungers, showers, changing cabins, and waiter service. Around €25–€35 per person in high season.

*Zone 4 — La Scogliera deck*
Premium teak decks on the rocks with ladders into deep water. Packages start around €100 for back-row loungers and can exceed €400 for front-row VIP.

For layout photos and current tips:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/positano-main-beach>

subject: Spiaggia Grande — Beach Clubs (L'Incanto and La Scogliera)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you are planning to rent a lounger at Spiaggia Grande, here is what to expect from the two clubs.

*L'Incanto (Zone 3)*
Orange loungers with showers, changing cabins, and waiter service. Standard packages run around €25–€35 per person in high season. In July and August, reserve by WhatsApp or email. Walk-ins before 09:30 are often possible in shoulder months. Blu Bar on the promenade serves pizza, salads, and aperitivi.

*La Scogliera (Zone 4)*
Premium teak decks carved into the rocks with ladders into deep water and an upstairs restaurant. Back-row packages start around €100; panoramic VIP options can exceed €400. Reservations are essential — message at least a day ahead for the best spots.

subject: Getting Back from Spiaggia Grande to the Hostel

1. Find the bus stop at Piazza dei Mulini — blue and white sign on a metal pole, near the pharmacy.

subject: Getting to Fornillo Beach from the Hostel
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fornillo is the closest full beach to the hostel. There are two ways to get there.

*Route A — Direct staircase shortcut (15–20 min)*
Exit the hostel, cross Viale Pasitea, and follow the signed staircase route down. You arrive at the left-hand end of Fornillo (facing the sea), right next to the large free beach section. This is faster than Google Maps suggests — follow the staircase, not the road.

*Route B — Via Spiaggia Grande (30–35 min total)*
Walk or take the Interno bus down to Spiaggia Grande, then follow the coastal promenade past the harbour. Keep right through the signed archway and walk about five minutes to reach Fornillo on the right-hand side.

Route A is shorter and drops you straight at the free area. Route B is useful if you are already at the main beach and want to continue to Fornillo later in the day.

For the step-by-step guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/hostel-brikette-to-fornillo-beach>

subject: Fornillo Beach — Free Area Tips
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fornillo has one of the best free public areas of any Positano beach. Here is how to make the most of it.

The largest free section sits at the left-hand end of the beach (facing the sea), directly in front of the staircase shortcut from the hostel. In high season it fills up fast: arrive before 10:30 to get a spot near the waterline.

Practical tips:

   - Water shoes are essential — the pebbles heat up and can be sharp, and sea urchins cluster near the rocky edges
   - Bring a thick mat or towel (a thin towel on pebbles is uncomfortable)
   - Carry a refillable bottle and a hat — shade is limited outside the club areas
   - You can buy food and drinks from Pupetto and Da Ferdinando without renting a lounger
   - Keep your valuables locked at the hostel and carry only what you need

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/fornillo-beach-guide>

subject: Fornillo Beach — Beach Club Options
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fornillo has four beach clubs, each with a slightly different character.

*Pupetto* — Orange loungers, showers, and a full-service restaurant on the hostel side of the beach. Good for a classic lido day without the Spiaggia Grande crowd. Reserve by WhatsApp or phone for weekends; walk-ins before 09:30 usually find a spot.

*Da Ferdinando* — Blue loungers with a chilled beach-bar vibe, paddleboard rentals, and a popular lunch menu. Close to the path back towards Spiaggia Grande, so easy to continue beach-hopping from here.

*Fratelli Grassi* — Compact setup with red loungers and a shaded bar for granita and cocktails. Social, hostel-friendly atmosphere; kayak rentals available. Advance booking recommended on weekends.

*La Marinella* — Closest to the Spiaggia Grande walkway, with attentive service and sometimes an upper deck for extra shade. A natural choice if you want an easy exit back towards town.

For more tips and club contacts:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/fornillo-beach-guide>

subject: Fornillo — The Quieter Free Cove Beyond La Marinella
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you want the quietest spot at Fornillo, walk past the last beach club (La Marinella) and you will find a small free cove that most visitors miss.

It is not a secret, but it is easy to overlook if you stop at the first club you reach. What to expect:

   - Calmer water, often good for a peaceful swim or short snorkel
   - Much less noise than the main beach area
   - Occasionally, spare loungers placed here by lido staff — but the zone is officially free public beach

Two things to know before you go:

   - The entry is rockier than the main free section — water shoes are strongly recommended
   - Sea urchins cluster near the edges, so stay in the central swim area and keep shoes on until you are properly in the water

For the full Fornillo guide:

subject: Getting Back from Fornillo Beach to the Hostel
body:

3. Turn left and follow the lane uphill to the Chiesa Nuova bus stop.

subject: Arienzo Beach — The Stairs: What to Expect (~300 Steps)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Arienzo Beach is beautiful, but getting there by foot involves roughly 300 stairs from the coastal road. Here is an honest picture.

*Going down*
Manageable if you take it slowly and use the patches of shade. Wear sturdy sandals or trainers — the stairs are steep and uneven in places.

*Coming back up*
This is the harder part. Allow 15–25 minutes. Carry weight in a backpack rather than a beach bag, and take breaks on the landings — everyone does.

*If you have knee pain or an injury*
Choose the shuttle boat as your only access route. The stairs can ruin your evening if you push through on bad knees.

*Agree your return plan early*
Before you settle in, confirm: are you taking the last shuttle boat, or climbing out and catching the bus? The stairs feel much longer in the afternoon heat.

subject: Getting to Gavitella Beach (Praiano)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Gavitella Beach sits below Praiano's Piazza San Gennaro — west-facing and famous for sunset. From the hostel it is about a 25-minute bus ride plus a descent of roughly 400 steps.

*Getting there*

   - Board the SITA bus at the Chiesa Nuova stop (Bar Internazionale, ~140 m from the hostel) toward Amalfi

subject: Gavitella — La Gavitella vs One Fire Beach Club
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Gavitella has two beach clubs with different vibes — here is a comparison to help you choose.

Classic seafood restaurant, aperitivi, and an optional evening boat cruise. Slow lunch, sunset on the loungers.

   - Boat shuttle add-on (when available): €10–€20 per person each way
   - Reserve by WhatsApp; weekends sell out June–September

   - Book via WhatsApp; peak-season slots go fast

   - A narrow free public strip sits between the clubs — it fills fast and may disappear in rough seas
   - Boat shuttles are weather-dependent: confirm your return boat before sunset or you will be climbing the 400 stairs
   - The ~400 uneven steps each way are not suitable for wheelchairs or heavy luggage — pack light

<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/gavitella-beach-guide>

subject: Getting to Marina di Praia (Praiano)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Marina di Praia is a sheltered pebble cove in Praiano — about 20 minutes by bus from Positano with calmer water than most of the coast.

*Getting there*

1. Walk 10 minutes downhill from the hostel to the Sponda stop on Via Pasitea.
2. Board the SITA bus toward Amalfi and ask the driver for "Marina di Praia."
3. Follow the stone path downhill from the bus stop — about 2 minutes to the beach.

   - Buy your return ticket at the same time — sellers are unreliable near the cove

subject: Marina di Praia — Facilities, Food, and Getting Back

subject: Combining Fiordo di Furore and Marina di Praia — Same Bus
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fiordo di Furore and Marina di Praia are on the same SITA bus line, a couple of stops apart — making them easy to pair in one day.

*Suggested plan*

1. Morning: bus from Sponda toward Amalfi, stop at Fiordo di Furore first. Spend 60–120 minutes: swim, take photos under the arched bridge, and explore the gorge.
2. Re-board the same bus for two more stops to Marina di Praia. Arrive in time for lunch and an afternoon on the beach.
3. Last SITA bus toward Positano from Marina di Praia runs until around 21:30 in summer — check timetable on arrival and aim for the second-to-last service.

*Ticket note*

Buy a round-trip ticket at Bar Internazionale before you leave the hostel. There are no ticket vendors at Fiordo di Furore, and sellers near Marina di Praia are unreliable.

subject: Getting to Fiordo di Furore by Bus
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fiordo di Furore is about 25 minutes by SITA bus from Positano.

1. Walk 10 minutes downhill from the hostel to the Sponda stop on Via Pasitea.
2. Board the SITA bus toward Amalfi and tell the driver "Fiordo di Furore" — the stop is on request.
3. The bus stops on the SS163 coastal road near the arched bridge. The staircase down to the gorge is visible from the roadside.

*Before you go*

   - Buy a round-trip ticket at Bar Internazionale before you leave the hostel — there are no ticket offices at the gorge and no sellers nearby
   - In peak months, buses sometimes skip the stop when full; allow extra time for the return
   - Go to the toilet before you leave Positano — there are no facilities at the fiord

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/fiordo-di-furore-beach-guide>

subject: Fiordo di Furore — What to Expect
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Fiordo di Furore is a tiny pebble pocket at the bottom of a gorge under a famous arched bridge. Entry is free — but there are no beach clubs, no reliable bathrooms, no changing rooms, and no food or drink kiosks (occasionally a small seasonal cart appears in peak season, but do not count on it).

This is best treated as a dramatic 60–120 minute stop rather than a full beach day.

*Tips*

   - Arrive before late morning in peak summer for fewer crowds and calmer water
   - The gorge is narrow and shade arrives early in the afternoon — plan your swim time first
   - Best photo angle: from the beach looking up toward the arched bridge
   - Step aside on wider stair landings for photos; never stop mid-staircase
   - After storms, the access steps can be slick with algae — take care and keep one hand free

Pair it with Marina di Praia (a couple of bus stops further) for a full beach day.

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/fiordo-di-furore-beach-guide>

subject: Fiordo di Furore — Swimming and Cliff Jumping Safety
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

The water at Fiordo di Furore is usually clear, but the entry is rocky and the gorge is narrow. Here is what to know before you swim.

*Swimming*

   - Enter slowly using the natural rock shelves — there is no formal ladder
   - Avoid diving unless you have personally checked the depth at that spot
   - The channel gets crowded at peak times; wait for space before entering
   - No lifeguard is present

*Cliff jumping*

Cliff jumping happens at the gorge, but it is not a casual activity:

   - Only jump from the same spots where experienced local swimmers are actively jumping
   - Never jump alone
   - Only on calm days — skip entirely if the sea is rough or visibility is poor
   - Not for beginners or first-time visitors to the gorge

If you are unsure, watch and enjoy — the gorge is beautiful without jumping.

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/fiordo-di-furore-beach-guide>

subject: Getting to Bagni della Regina Giovanna (Sorrento Day)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Bagni della Regina Giovanna is a free natural sea pool west of Sorrento — a Roman villa ruin sits above, and the swim is beautiful on a calm morning.

*Getting there (allow about 1 hour each way)*

1. SITA bus from Bar Internazionale toward Sorrento.
2. EAV local bus A or C from Sorrento to Capo di Sorrento (€1.50 — buy in advance).
3. Walk 1.1 km along Via Capo; at number 49 turn into the pedestrian-only lane downhill (~10 min to the ruins, then 5 more minutes down stone steps to the cove).

*What to bring*

   - Water shoes — the path is uneven and slippery when wet
   - At least 1.5 litres of water per person in peak summer
   - Screenshot your return bus and ferry times before descending — mobile signal is patchy near the rocks
   - No facilities on-site: use Sorrento restrooms before boarding the local bus

*Getting back*

   - Return the same way; if you miss the bus, a taxi back to Sorrento costs around €18–€22 for up to four people

subject: Beach-Hopping Day — Spiaggia Grande, Amalfi, Laurito or Arienzo
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

For guests who want to pack a lot into one day, here is a multi-beach plan that combines swimming, a ferry lunch, and a golden-hour sunset swim.

*Morning: Spiaggia Grande → Fornillo*

*Midday: Ferry to Amalfi*

subject: Path of the Gods — Amalfi Bus Route (Bomerano to Nocelle)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

This is the budget-friendly way to do the Path of the Gods: three SITA bus legs and a 2.5–3 hour hike from Bomerano to Nocelle.

*Before you leave the hostel*
Buy three SITA tickets per person at Bar Internazionale (just 2 minutes from the hostel): Positano → Amalfi, Amalfi → Bomerano, and Nocelle → Positano. Keep a spare ticket in case you need it.

*Bus 1 — Positano to Amalfi (45–60 min)*
Wait on the opposite side of the road from Bar Internazionale. Validate when boarding. Sit on the right-hand side for sweeping coastal views. Arrive Amalfi terminal and stay near the bus bays for your transfer.

*Bus 2 — Amalfi to Bomerano*
Board the service marked "Agerola/Bomerano." Alight at the Bomerano stop opposite Ristorante Jerla. Cross the road, take the side street to the piazza, then follow Sentiero degli Dei signs to the trailhead.

*Hike — Bomerano to Nocelle (2.5–3 hours)*
Follow the CAI waymarks across the terraces and ridge. Carry water and snacks — there are no facilities between Bomerano and Nocelle.

*Nocelle: critical navigation*
When the path turns to concrete, you are in Nocelle. Turn RIGHT — do NOT follow the signs to Positano down the stairs (that is a strenuous 1,700-step descent). Walk ~175 m to the small car park and bus shelter.

*Bus 3 — Return to Positano*
Use your final ticket for the Nocelle/Montepertuso bus back to Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova.

For the full route guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/path-of-the-gods-bus>

subject: Path of the Gods — Ferry Route via Amalfi
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

The ferry route combines a scenic sea crossing to Amalfi with the full Bomerano-to-Nocelle hike. More scenic than the all-bus option; slightly more expensive and weather-dependent.

*Before you go — check conditions*
Rough seas can cancel ferries with little notice. Check the harbour board or ask reception the evening before. If the sea is rough, use the all-bus route instead.

*Ferry — Positano to Amalfi (~25 min)*
Walk 20–30 minutes down to the ferry pier. Arrive at least 15 minutes before departure. Ferry operators include Lucibello and Travelmar; tickets cost €12–€16 one way. Services depart every 30–60 minutes in season.

*In Amalfi — transfer to bus*
Buy three SITA bus tickets at the Amalfi terminal: Amalfi → Bomerano, Nocelle → Positano, plus a spare. Board the service marked "Agerola/Bomerano." Alight at Bomerano opposite Ristorante Jerla.

*Hike — Bomerano to Nocelle (2.5–3 hours)*
Follow the piazza through to the Sentiero degli Dei signs and hike the ridge. No facilities between Bomerano and Nocelle — bring water.

*Nocelle: critical navigation*
Turn RIGHT when the path turns to concrete. Do NOT follow the stairs to Positano. Walk ~175 m to the car park bus shelter for the return bus.

For the full route guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/path-of-the-gods-ferry>

subject: Path of the Gods — Nocelle Shuttle (Easiest Option)
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

The Nocelle shuttle is the simplest way to experience the Path of the Gods: take a short bus ride up to the trailhead, hike out-and-back, and ride the same bus home. No ferry timing, no Amalfi transfer.

*Before you go*
Buy two bus tickets per person at Bar Internazionale: Positano → Nocelle and Nocelle → Positano (€1.80–€2.40 per leg). Check the Montepertuso–Nocelle timetable — afternoon buses run less frequently; plan a morning departure.

*Bus up to Nocelle*
Board the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus from Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova. Validate your ticket. Stay on until the final stop — a small car park where the bus turns around.

*Walk to the trail*
Walk down the steps from the car park. At the bottom, turn left through Nocelle village following Sentiero degli Dei signs. At the key junction, ignore the signs pointing down the stairs to Positano — continue toward the trail entrance.

*Hike out-and-back*
Walk toward Colle Serra for the best viewpoints. Turn around whenever you are ready — most hikers go 45–60 minutes out for the classic panoramas, then retrace their steps. Full hike is approximately 3 hours. Bring water; there are no facilities along the trail.

*Return*
Use your return ticket for the bus back to Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova. If you miss the bus, the paved road to Positano is about 4 km (45–60 min walk).

For the full route guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/path-of-the-gods-nocelle>

subject: Sunrise Hike from the Hostel
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

For an easy pre-breakfast adventure, there is a short sunrise hike starting almost from the hostel door.

*What to bring*

   - Headlamp or phone torch (fully charged)
   - Grip shoes or trainers — the steps can be slippery in the dark
   - A layer for the top

*Route*
1. Walk ~350 m toward Sorrento along the main road from the hostel.
2. Take the staircase uphill. Climb to the old white house and turn left onto the woodland trail.
3. At the fork, take the right branch and continue until the sea comes into view.
4. Turn left to reach the viewpoint.
5. Start 10–15 minutes before sunrise to be in position when the light arrives.

*Fallback plan*
If the trail feels slippery after rain the night before, watch from the hostel terrace instead — the sun rises from the left when you are facing the sea, and the view is still excellent.

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/sunrise-hike>

subject: Santa Maria del Castello Hike
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Santa Maria del Castello sits at 670 m above Positano. It is significantly more strenuous than the Path of the Gods, but you earn sweeping Amalfi Coast views within 15 minutes of leaving the hostel, and the village has a restaurant where you can recover.

*Key directions (condensed — the full guide has navigation photos)*
1. Turn right and climb the steps up the side of the building.
2. Continue on the footpath; at the junction turn left (uphill, not downhill).
3. Cross the road and take the next staircase alongside the houses.
4. Follow the mountain trail uphill, taking the uphill branch at the two forks.
5. At the crossroads at the top, turn right for the lookout.

*At the top*
The restaurant in the village serves affordable meals — a good reason to linger. At the lookout: the vantage has sudden drop-offs of several hundred metres — stay well back and supervise children.

*Timing*

   - Start before 11:00 in summer to avoid the worst of the heat on the exposed upper trail
   - Allow at least 1.5–3 hours depending on pace

For the full step-by-step guide with navigation photos:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/santa-maria-del-castello-hike>

subject: Top of the Mountain Hike — Monte Sant'Angelo
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Monte Sant'Angelo (also called Monte Comune) is the highest point on the Amalfi Coast. This is a full-day commitment — not suitable for casual walkers.

*Do not attempt without:*

   - Mountain experience and comfort on exposed ledges
   - Strong physical fitness
   - At least 2 litres of water per person + salty snacks (no reliable refills after Santa Maria del Castello)
   - Solid hiking shoes with grip (rock sections are loose and exposed)

*What to expect*

   - 6–7 hours round trip from the hostel, including breaks and summit time
   - Start at Santa Maria del Castello — this represents roughly one-third of total elevation
   - From the village crossroads, continue on the mountain trail to the upper switchbacks, then rock-cut stairs to the summit plateau
   - Views include Capri visible from the ridge on clear days
   - Acceptable turn-back points: Santa Maria del Castello viewpoint or the lower switchbacks

*Conditions*

   - Avoid summer afternoons — heat and water strain are punishing
   - Summit steps are slippery after storms
   - Wind can whip across the ridge even on warm days

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/top-of-the-mountain-hike>

subject: Photography — Best Spots, Golden Hour, and Etiquette
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Here are the best photography spots in and around Positano, with timing and etiquette notes.

*Top spots*

   - Church of Santa Maria Assunta steps: arrive just after sunrise — empty beach, warm dome glow, soft light before the crowds
   - Ferry pier: wide-angle shot toward the cliffside; arrive before 09:00 (queues form after)
   - Via Trara Genoino viewpoint (above Fornillo): layered shot of fishing boats and pastel houses
   - Via Cristoforo Colombo benches: 45 minutes before sunset for the Li Galli islands backdrop in summer
   - Chiesa Nuova terrace (near the SITA stop): sweeping bay view, easy access
   - Via Positanesi d'America: balcony above Fornillo; arrive 30 minutes before sunset
   - Nocelle via bus: unbeatable panorama on clear mornings — take the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus

*Timing rule of thumb*
Sunrise gives emptier streets and softer light. Sunset attracts more people but the cliff lights up from the west. Arrive 20 minutes before golden hour to claim your spot.

*Drone regulations*
Italian regulations require permits; fines for unlicensed flights are hefty. Avoid drones inside town limits entirely.

*Etiquette*

   - Keep tripods compact and step aside once you have your frame — keep staircases passable
   - Do not pose on hotel terraces unless you are a guest
   - Ask staff before setting up on private property
   - Bring a phone torch for late descents — street lighting varies

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/instagram-spots>

subject: Capri Day Trip — Full Guide
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Capri is the standout day trip from Positano — about 30–60 minutes by ferry and a full day well spent.

*Getting there*
Walk 15–20 minutes downhill to the pier. Arrive at least 20–30 minutes before departure — each operator has its own ticket booth. Ferry tickets cost €18–€25 one way. Sit on the right side for the best coastal views leaving Positano.

*On arrival in Capri — first thing*
Book your return ferry as soon as you disembark at Marina Grande. The 16:00–17:00 return slots sell out quickly in summer. Lock in your time and then explore freely.

*Suggested order*
Head to Anacapri first (quieter, cooler). Take the Monte Solaro chairlift (€16–€18 return) to the island's highest point. Return to Capri town for lunch and the Giardini di Augusto (€1–€2) overlooking the Faraglioni rocks.

*Blue Grotto*
Entry €14–€18 plus a rowboat fee. Important: confirm the grotto is actually operating before joining the queue — operators sometimes sell tickets even when it is closed due to swell.

*Via Krupp*
This scenic footpath is frequently closed due to rockfall. Check locally before planning your route around it.

*Budget*
Allow €70–€120 per person for ferry, chairlift, entry fees, and a light lunch. Giardini di Augusto, Piazzetta, and free beaches keep optional costs manageable.

*Ferries in rough seas*
Check morning bulletins — cancellations happen with as little as 90 minutes notice.

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/capri-day-trip>

subject: Pompeii Day Trip — Step by Step
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Pompeii is the easiest big ruin day trip from Positano — about €30–€40 all-in and entirely doable without a tour.

*Getting there*
1. Leave the hostel around 08:00.
2. SITA bus from Bar Internazionale to Sorrento (50–60 min, €2.50–€3.00).
3. 5-minute walk to the Circumvesuviana station (near Piazza Tasso).
4. Train to **Pompei Scavi – Villa dei Misteri** (30–35 min, €3–€4). This is the correct station — do not exit at the earlier "Pompeii" stop.
5. Entrance is at Porta Marina Superiore, a short walk from the station.

*Before you go*
Pre-book tickets online to skip 30–60 minute queues: ticketone.it or the official Pompeii site. Entry €16–€18.

*At the site*
Pompeii is 66 hectares — allow 3–4 hours minimum. Get the free map at the entrance. Packed lunch recommended (the site café is overpriced). Bring at least 1.5 litres of water per person — summer heat is punishing.

*Wear sturdy closed-toe shoes.* Sandals on Pompeii's uneven stone streets cause twisted ankles.

*Circumvesuviana tip:* Keep valuables in a front pocket — the train attracts pickpockets.

*Back to Positano:* Return train to Sorrento, then SITA bus. Afternoon buses are packed — allow extra time or split a taxi from Sorrento (€60–€80 for four people).

For the full guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/positano-pompeii>

subject: Amalfi Town and Ravello — Combined Day
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Amalfi and Ravello pair perfectly — ferry or bus to Amalfi, then a short bus up to Ravello for hilltop views and gardens.

*Getting to Amalfi*

   - Ferry from the pier: €10–€18, 20–30 minutes (April–October)
   - SITA bus from Bar Internazionale: €4, 40 minutes (runs year-round)

*In Amalfi*
The Duomo is free to enter the main nave; the Cloister of Paradise costs €3. Allow 1–2 hours to explore the old town and the harbour.

*Bus to Ravello*
Take the SITA 5110 bus from Amalfi (€2.50, 25 minutes of hairpin bends). In summer this bus gets very busy — get a seat toward the front if you are prone to motion sickness, and arrive early.

*In Ravello*

   - Villa Cimbrone (Terrace of Infinity): €10 — the highlight of the trip on a clear day
   - Villa Rufolo: €7
   - Free public terraces and belvederes around the village: sweeping views at no cost
   - Ravello Festival (June–September): classical concerts — check the schedule if your dates overlap

Total for the combined day: roughly €15–€26 depending on transport choice and which villas you visit.

For the full day trips guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/day-trips-amalfi>

subject: Sorrento Half-Day
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Sorrento makes an excellent half-day trip — and almost all the best bits are free.

*Getting there*

   - Ferry from the pier: €12, 30 minutes (April–October)
   - SITA bus from Bar Internazionale: €4, 50 minutes (runs year-round)

*Free highlights*

   - Villa Comunale: park with terrace views over the Bay of Naples — free
   - Sedil Dominova: historic loggia with original 15th-century frescoed ceilings — free, easy to miss
   - Chiostro di San Francesco: quiet cloister garden — free
   - Marina Grande: the old fishing harbour, 10-minute steep walk down from the main square — free beach and great photos

*Food and drink*

   - Gelato: I Giardini di Cataldo or Davide Gelato are local favourites (€3–€4 cone)
   - Limoncello: buy from an alimentari or grocery store (€8–€10) rather than the tourist shops near Piazza Tasso (€15–€20)
   - Lunch: side streets off Via Fuoro or Via Tasso have good-value trattorias; €8–€12 pizza

For the full Sorrento guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/sorrento-guide>

subject: Herculaneum — Half-Day Alternative to Pompeii
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If Pompeii feels too big or the summer heat is brutal, Herculaneum is the smarter choice — better preserved, far less overwhelming, and done in half the time.

*Getting there*
1. SITA bus from Bar Internazionale to Sorrento (50–60 min, ~€2.50).
2. Circumvesuviana train from Sorrento to **Ercolano Scavi** (20 minutes, ~€2.50). This is two stops before the Pompeii station.
3. Short walk to the entrance.

*Why Herculaneum?*

   - Only 4.5 hectares vs Pompeii's 66 — you can see the whole site in 1.5–2 hours
   - Buried under 20 metres of volcanic material instead of 6 — wood, cloth, and food were preserved
   - Upper floors and roofs still intact in many buildings
   - Entry €13; total budget ~€27–€35 all-in

*Same Circumvesuviana tip applies:* keep valuables in a front pocket.

*Best for:* limited time, very hot days (shorter outdoor exposure), anyone who wants detail over scale.

For the full day trips guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/positano-pompeii>

subject: Boat Tours — Group and Private Options
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

A boat tour is one of the best ways to see the Amalfi Coast — the sea view of the cliffs, grottos, and village stacks is completely different to anything from the road.

   - Price: €85–€120 per person

Ask at reception for current availability and to arrange booking.

subject: Getting to the Capri Ferry — Walk and Timing
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Here is exactly how to get from Hostel Brikette to the Capri ferry.

*Walk to the pier (15–20 minutes downhill)*
Leave the hostel and head downhill via the staircase paths toward the beach. Follow signs to the port/Spiaggia Grande. The pier has ticket booths at water level — each operator has its own booth, so check which one your ticket is with.

*Arrive early*
In peak season (July–August), arrive at least 20–30 minutes before departure to exchange vouchers and join the queue. Morning services sell out fastest.

*Cancellations*
Ferries can be cancelled in rough seas with as little as 90 minutes notice. Check the morning harbour bulletin if the weather looks uncertain.

*Backup plan if ferries are cancelled*
Take the SITA bus to Sorrento, then catch a Sorrento–Capri ferry (which runs a slightly shorter crossing). Total journey from Positano: 90–120 minutes.

*Best views on the crossing*
Sit on the right side (starboard) when departing Positano for the full cliff and village panorama.

For the full Capri ferry guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/positano-capri-ferry>

subject: Which Day Trip? — A Decision Guide
body:

Not sure which day trip to do? Here is a quick guide based on conditions, time, and budget.

*Clear weather + full day available*

   - **Best experience:** Capri by ferry (€18–€25 ferry + ~€40 on island)
   - **Best value + culture:** Amalfi town + Ravello by bus (€15–€26 total)

*Rough seas or rainy day*

   - **Best option:** Pompeii by bus + Circumvesuviana (€30–€40 total, all inland)
   - **Shorter option:** Herculaneum — same route, just 1.5–2 hours on site (€27–€35 total)
   - **Easy option:** Sorrento half-day by bus (€4–€8 return, mostly free attractions)

*Only a half day*

   - Morning: Amalfi by bus (40 min each way, €4 return) — enough time for the Duomo and harbour
   - Morning: Sorrento by bus (50 min each way, €4 return) — Marina Grande, Villa Comunale, gelato

*Budget under €30*

   - Pompeii (~€30–€40), Herculaneum (~€27), or Amalfi+Ravello by bus (~€15)

*Special occasion or wow factor*

   - Capri full day, or ask about the sunset cruise and dinner (€139/person, speak to reception)

Avoid July/August midday heat at outdoor sites (Pompeii especially) — go early or choose a shaded option.

For more detail on all day trips:

subject: 1–3 Day Positano Itinerary
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Here is a suggested itinerary depending on how many days you have in Positano.

*Day 1 — Arrival and town*
Head to Spiaggia Grande early for a swim before the beach clubs fill up. Walk the coastal path to Fornillo for a quieter afternoon (free public strip, 15–20 min walk from the hostel). Evening: sunset at Via Cristoforo Colombo (45 min before sunset for the Li Galli islands shot) or the hostel terrace.

*Day 2 — Path of the Gods and beach*
Morning: take the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus to Nocelle (€1.80–€2.40 each way) and hike out-and-back on the Sentiero degli Dei toward Colle Serra (~3 hours total). Return by bus. Afternoon: pick a beach — Laurito by boat for something special, or Fornillo for a chill wind-down.

*Day 3 — Day trip*
Choose your adventure:

   - Capri by ferry (clear weather, full experience, ~€70–€120)
   - Amalfi + Ravello by bus (great value, easy, ~€15–€26)
   - Pompeii (ruins, culture, all-inland option for rough sea days, ~€30–€40)

*Budget version:*
SITA buses instead of ferries everywhere, packed lunches, hostel terrace for sunset. Day 3: Amalfi+Ravello by bus or Herculaneum (~€27).

For detailed guides on each activity, ask at reception or explore our guide library at:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/backpacker-itineraries>

subject: Arriving by Car — ZTL, Garages, and Alternatives
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you are arriving by car, here is what to know before you drive into Positano.

**ZTL zones and SS163 restrictions**

   - Positano and nearby towns use ZTL (restricted traffic zones); cameras enforce entry at restricted times
   - Fines can arrive months later; rental-car companies add admin fees on top
   - April–October: the SS163 (Amalfi Coast road) may have alternated-plate restrictions — check current rules for your travel dates

**Arrival plan**

   - Drop luggage near Chiesa Nuova first, then go park — do not carry heavy bags up from a garage
   - Do not stop in yellow-line or no-stopping zones on the main road; enforcement is strict

**Parking options**

   - Private garages (book ahead): Mandara, Car Park Anna, Di Gennaro
   - Typical cost: €35–€60 per 24 hours in peak months; height limit approx. 1.9 m / 6.2 ft
   - Book July–August arrivals a week or more in advance

**Best option for most guests**

   - Park in Sorrento, Meta, Piano di Sorrento, or near Salerno port
   - Finish the journey by SITA bus (€2.50) or seasonal ferry
   - Often cheaper and far less stressful than driving into Positano

Full guide including driving tips and free-parking notes:

body:

body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

**Landmark route (5 points)**

   1. Exit the hostel; turn left along the road and walk approx. 100 m to the first turn-off (Point 1) — there is a tabacchi on the right just after you turn
   2. Follow the road downhill to the first switchback bend (Point 2); leave the road and take the stairs straight ahead

   - Walk to the end of the pier and wait for your ferry to call boarding

subject: Ferry Cancellations — What to Do
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Ferry services can be suspended with little notice when seas are rough. Here is what to do.

**When cancellations happen**

   - Sailings are typically suspended when winds exceed 20 knots or swell exceeds 1.5 m (~5 ft)
   - Check operator websites (Travelmar, Alilauro, NLG) and port display boards every 30 minutes on windy days
   - Morning sailings are the most reliable; avoid relying on the last boat when storms are forecast

**Land backup route**

   - For Amalfi/Salerno: take the SITA bus from Chiesa Nuova (eastbound, sea-view side); buy ticket at Bar Internazionale or tabacchi
   - For Sorrento/Naples: take the SITA bus (westbound, mountain side); connect to Circumvesuviana at Sorrento
   - Allow at least 60 minutes buffer when switching to buses — they can arrive full in peak season

**Refunds**

   - Keep your receipt or screenshot the QR code — show at the dock booth for a refund or rebooking
   - For bookings made through an online agency: email the cancellation notice screenshot within 24 hours

**If you are already away from Positano**

   - Notify your accommodation as soon as delays are announced
   - Ask the port information point about shared taxis or substitute shuttles

Full guide including insurance tips:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/ferry-cancellations>

subject: Summer Bus Queue Tips
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

In summer, SITA buses on the Amalfi Coast fill quickly. A few tips to make sure you get on yours.

   - Busiest windows: 09:00–12:00 and 16:00–19:00, June–September
   - Arrive at the Chiesa Nuova stop 10–15 minutes before your bus in these windows

   - Summer last bus to Amalfi: approx. 10:30pm; to Sorrento: approx. 11:00pm

   - Always check the timetable at the stop on the day — times vary seasonally

subject: Budget Transport — Day Passes and Money-Saving Tips
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

A few ways to keep transport costs down on the Amalfi Coast.

**Three day passes — know the difference**

   - 24-hour Costiera pass: €8.00 — unlimited SITA buses on the Sorrento–Salerno corridor
   - COSTIERASITA 24-hour pass: €10 — similar SITA bus coverage, slightly different product
   - UNICO Costiera day pass: €12.40 — broader regional pass including some train connections
   - Validate on your first ride and keep the ticket; inspectors do check
   - Worth buying any of these if you are making 3 or more separate bus trips in one day

**Off-peak travel**

   - Buses before 08:30 and after 19:00 are quieter and easier for luggage
   - Morning ferries are more reliable and less crowded than afternoon departures

**Other savings**

   - Walk to the Chiesa Nuova stop yourself instead of arranging a porter for manageable luggage (allow 15 min)
   - Luggage storage near the ferry dock: approx. €7–€10 — often cheaper than an extra taxi trip to drop bags
   - Late-night returns: split a shared taxi (approx. €80 total, ~€20 per person for four) rather than waiting for buses that may not come

Full transport-on-a-budget guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/transport-budget>

Positano can be expensive but there are good ways to keep food costs down.

**Cheapest options**

   - Pizza al taglio (by the slice): €3–€5 before noon from bakeries — best value in town
   - Espresso al banco (standing at the bar): €1.20–€1.50
   - Water: ask for "acqua del rubinetto" (tap water) — free at most places; there is also a public fountain near the Chiesa Nuova bus stop
   - Supermarket 1.5L bottles: around €0.80

**Cheaper restaurants**

   - Trattorias uphill from the seafront are typically 20–30% cheaper than beachside spots
   - A menu del giorno (set lunch) costs €12–€18 and usually includes pasta, water, and coffee

**Daily food budget rough guide**

   - Budget: €15–€25/day (supermarket meals, pizza al taglio, one sit-down lunch)

subject: What to Pack — Footwear and Luggage for Positano
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Positano's stairs and steep terrain make footwear and luggage choices more important than most destinations.

**Footwear — the most important decision**

   - Bring walking shoes or trainers with good grip — polished stone steps are slippery, especially when wet
   - Smooth-soled shoes, flat-soled fashion trainers, and heels are not suitable; heels are dangerous on stairs
   - Water shoes or sturdy sandals with straps for pebble beaches — most Positano beaches are shingle, not sand
   - Do not arrive in brand-new shoes; break them in before the trip — blisters plus steep stairs is a bad combination

**Luggage**

   - Backpacks and soft-sided duffel bags are much easier than wheeled suitcases on stairs
   - Rolling suitcases will need to be carried on stairs multiple times — keep them as light as possible
   - Aim for carry-on size if you can
   - Day bag: keep it under 15L for buses and boats — large daypacks on crowded transport are awkward for everyone

subject: What to Pack — Seasonal Clothing and Sun Protection
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Here is what changes by season and what to know about sun protection.

**Summer (June–September)**

   - Hot and dry: 25–32°C (77–90°F)
   - Lightweight, breathable clothing; hat, sunglasses, and SPF 50+ sunscreen are essential
   - One light layer for evenings — air-conditioned restaurants can feel cool after a warm day
   - Sunscreen costs €15–€25 for 200ml locally — bring enough from home to save money

**Spring (March–May)**

   - Mornings 12–15°C, afternoons 18–22°C — layers are important
   - Light rain jacket; April showers are common; sunscreen is still essential

**Autumn (October–November)**

   - 15–23°C; waterproof shoes and a compact umbrella; the ocean stays swimmable through October

**Winter (December–February)**

   - 8–15°C; proper rain jacket, warm layers, and grip shoes for wet stairs
   - Many beach clubs close but hiking is excellent in winter

**Power adapter**

   - Italy uses Type L (3-prong) and Type C (2-prong European) plugs at 230V
   - Bring a universal adapter or buy one from a tabacchi for around €5–€10

subject: Hitchhiking the Amalfi Coast — What to Know
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Hitchhiking on the Amalfi Coast sounds adventurous but the SS163 is genuinely not safe for it.

**Why it does not work here**

   - The SS163 is narrow with blind bends and almost no safe pull-offs — drivers cannot stop in time
   - Coaches, buses, and scooters already share a single lane carved into the cliff
   - Night visibility is poor and road shoulders are tiny; waiting on the carriageway risks injury
   - Police will often move people on for their own safety; fines are possible
   - Never wait inside tunnels or on blind bends

**What to do instead**

   - SITA buses run all day between major towns; buy tickets at a tabacchi and validate on board
   - Seasonal ferries give scenic hops between towns; when seas cancel them, the SITA bus is the reliable backup
   - Short walking paths connect some villages in daylight (Nocelle ↔ Positano, Praiano ↔ coastal hamlets)

**If you are stranded**

   - Taxi numbers are posted at major bus stops; the hostel bar can call a licensed taxi for you
   - Late-night taxi rates are higher — split the fare with other travellers when possible
   - Message us if you are stuck; we can suggest the safest pickup point or an overnight option in Sorrento or Amalfi

   - Shared fridge in the common area
   - Kettle and microwave available for guest use

**House rules for shared food**

   - Please label your items with your name and room/bed number
   - Unlabelled or unclaimed items may be cleared out periodically
   - Be considerate of other guests when using shared appliances

If you have specific dietary needs or questions about meals nearby, reception can recommend options in Positano.

subject: Lower Bunk Requests
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

We understand some guests prefer a lower bunk, but unfortunately we cannot guarantee specific bed assignments in advance.

**How bed allocation works**

   - Beds in dorm rooms are allocated on a first-come, first-served basis at check-in
   - Arriving earlier in the check-in window (from 15:00) gives you the best chance of securing a lower bunk if one is available

**If you have mobility concerns**

   - Email us before your stay and we will do our best to accommodate you
   - If an upper bunk is not suitable for you due to a medical or mobility reason, a private room may be a better option — get in touch and we can check availability

Full check-in details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/check-in-checkout>

subject: Female-Only Dorm — Who Can Book
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Our female-only dorm is reserved exclusively for women and has its own ensuite bathroom.

**Booking rules**

   - Only women may book beds in the female-only dorm
   - Mixed-gender groups cannot book into this room — companions of a different gender will need to be assigned to a separate dorm or a private room
   - There are no exceptions to this policy

**Visitors**

   - Visitors are not permitted in any guest rooms, including the female-only dorm
   - Guests and their visitors may use the communal areas only

If you have questions about room options, email us before you book and we can advise on availability.

Full security and house rules:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/security>

subject: Deposits at Check-In — Two Separate Charges
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

There are two separate deposits collected at check-in. Here is what each covers.

**1. Safeguarding hold**

   - Amount: equivalent to one night's accommodation per guest
   - Collected at check-in as a card pre-authorisation (or cash alternative)
   - Covers any fines, additional fees, extensions, or damages incurred during your stay
   - Released or applied at checkout

**2. Keycard and linen deposit**

   - Amount: €10 per guest, paid in cash at check-in
   - Covers the keycard and linen provided for your stay
   - Fully refunded when you return your keycard and linen at checkout

These are two distinct charges — please bring cash for the keycard deposit.

Full deposits and payments details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/deposits-payments>

subject: Damage Charges — How They Are Calculated
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If damage occurs during a stay, charges are calculated based on the labour required to address it.

**Labour rates**

   - Director: €50 per hour
   - Manager: €35 per hour
   - Staff: €25 per hour

**How charges work**

   - The safeguarding deposit is applied first to cover any charges
   - If the cost exceeds the deposit, the guest is responsible for the balance
   - Material costs (replacement items, repairs) are charged at cost

**Reporting defects**

   - If you notice any damage or defects in your room on arrival, please report it to reception immediately so it is not attributed to your stay

Full details on defects and damages:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/defects-damages>

subject: Early Departure — How It Works
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you need to leave before your original checkout date, a refund is not automatic.

**What you need to do**

   - Email us as soon as you know you want to leave early — do not wait until the day
   - Shortening your stay is treated as a cancellation request for the remaining nights
   - Whether a refund applies depends on the rate type you booked and our written confirmation

**Important**

   - If you leave without sending a written cancellation request, the original booking terms remain in force
   - Non-refundable rates do not qualify for a refund on unused nights

To request an early departure, email us at hostelpositano@gmail.com with your booking reference and intended new checkout date.

Full cancellation and changes details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/changing-cancelling>

subject: Making Changes to Your Booking
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you need to make changes to your booking (dates, room type, or number of guests), here is how the process works.

**How changes work**

   - Booking changes are not made by modifying your existing booking in place
   - A change request creates a new booking; the original booking is cancelled and a new one is issued
   - Subject to availability at the time of the request

**What you need to do**

   - Email us at hostelpositano@gmail.com with your booking reference and the details of what you would like to change
   - Include your preferred new dates or room type so we can check availability straight away
   - Changes must be requested within the notice period allowed by your rate type

**Bookings are non-transferable** — they cannot be passed to another person.

Full cancellation and changes details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/changing-cancelling>

subject: Linen and Towels During a Longer Stay
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you are staying with us for more than a few nights, here is what to expect for linen and towel service.

**Linen**

   - Bed linen is changed every 4th night of your stay
   - Fresh linen will be provided automatically on the scheduled change night

**Towels**

   - Additional towels are available at reception at an extra charge
   - Beach towels are available to rent — ask at the bar or reception

**Common areas**

   - The bar, terrace, and lounge are available throughout your stay

If you have any questions about your room during a longer stay, come to reception and we will sort it out.

subject: Cancellation Fee — How It Is Applied
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

A cancellation admin fee of 15% of the booking price (excluding any third-party commissions) applies to all cancellations.

**How to cancel**

   - All cancellations must be submitted by email to hostelpositano@gmail.com
   - Include your booking reference and the reason for cancellation
   - Your booking remains active until you receive written confirmation from us — do not assume it is cancelled until you hear back

**No-show policy**

   - If you do not arrive and have not cancelled with sufficient notice, the booking will be treated as a no-show
   - No-show charges apply in full

**Non-refundable rates**

   - If you booked a non-refundable rate, no refund is issued regardless of when you cancel

Full cancellation and changes details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/changing-cancelling>

subject: Outside Alcohol — Our Policy
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Brikette is a licensed venue, which means outside alcohol is not permitted anywhere on the property.

**If you arrive with outside alcohol**

   - Staff will store it safely and return it to you at checkout, or once you confirm it will be consumed off-site
   - Our team's decision on this is final

**Serious breach**

   - Bringing or consuming outside alcohol on the premises can result in the booking being cancelled on the spot, treated as a No Show, with no refund issued

We appreciate your understanding — this keeps our bar licence in place for everyone.

Full house rules:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/rules>

subject: Unregistered Overnight Guest — What Happens
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Italian law requires every overnight guest to be registered. If an unregistered person is found staying in a room, the following applies.

**Charges**

   - The registered guest(s) will be charged the standard room rate for the unregistered person, plus an administrative fee equal to twice that amount

**What must happen next**

   - The additional person must complete check-in immediately or depart the property
   - If they decline to do either, the hostel is obliged to contact the local authorities

**Effect on your booking**

   - Not declaring an overnight guest may result in the booking being recorded as a No Show

If you have a guest who would like to stay overnight, please contact reception before they arrive so we can arrange it properly.

Full security information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/security>

subject: Bed Bugs — What to Do If You Suspect Them
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you notice any signs of bed bugs, please report it to reception immediately — do not wait.

**What to do right now**

   - Come to reception in person straight away
   - Do not move rooms or beds without staff instruction
   - Do not carry linens, soft items, or clothing through the property without guidance from staff

**Containment steps staff may ask you to take**

   - Bag affected belongings in sealed bags
   - Launder clothing and soft items as directed
   - Keep affected items separate from clean belongings

**Costs**

   - If bed bugs are identified during your stay, you may be responsible for associated costs including lost booking revenue, cleaning expenses, and pest control
   - Charges are based on evidence and governed by our booking terms

**Prevention**

   - Please let us know at check-in if you have recently stayed somewhere with known bed-bug problems
   - Inspect your luggage and clothing carefully before entering your room

Full defects and damages guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/defects-damages>

subject: Leaving Before 07:30 — Early Checkout Procedure
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you need to leave before 07:30, you must arrange this with reception the evening before your departure.

**Why you must arrange it the night before**

   - The €10 keycard and linen deposit is cash-only and can only be returned by staff at checkout
   - If you leave without confirming with reception and returning your keycard, the deposit will be forfeited
   - We cannot refund a deposit that is not processed through the checkout procedure

**What to do**

   - Come to reception the evening before your early departure
   - Return your keycard and linen and collect your €10 cash deposit
   - Confirm your departure time so staff can note it

Full check-in and checkout details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/check-in-checkout>

subject: Not Checked Out by 10:30 — What Happens
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Checkout time is 07:30–10:30. If you have not checked out by 10:30, the following applies.

**What we may do**

   - Pack and secure your belongings and move them to porter storage
   - Restrict access to the room and guest-only areas
   - Storage and handling costs will be charged to your booking

**Late checkout**

   - Late checkout is subject to availability and must be confirmed in writing before 10:30
   - If approved, it is valid until 12:00 and costs €40
   - Without written confirmation, the standard 10:30 checkout applies

**Unclaimed belongings**

   - Items left behind may be stored for 30 days and then disposed of or donated

Full check-in and checkout details:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/check-in-checkout>

subject: Contagious Illness — Refund Policy and What to Do
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you have been exposed to a contagious illness (including flu, respiratory infections, or similar viruses), please let us know.

**Refund policy**

   - Non-refundable bookings remain non-refundable even in the case of illness — this is stated in our booking terms
   - Refundable bookings follow the standard cancellation terms
   - We strongly recommend travel insurance to cover health-related disruptions

**If you are unwell during your stay**

   - Please inform reception immediately so we can support you and protect other guests
   - In an emergency, staff will contact Italian emergency services (112 / 118)
   - We cannot provide professional medical assistance on site

Full health and safety policy:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/legal>

subject: Service Animals — Booking Requirements
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

We welcome certified service animals at Hostel Brikette, but advance arrangement is required.

**What you need to know**

   - Certified service animals are permitted in private rooms only — they cannot be accommodated in shared dorms
   - Prior arrangement and documentation are required before your stay

**How to arrange it**

   - Email us before booking with your intended arrival date and the type of service animal
   - We will confirm what documentation is needed and which room we can offer
   - Do not book a dorm bed for a stay with a service animal — contact us first

Full accessibility information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/age-accessibility>

subject: CPAP and Assisted-Sleeping Devices — What You Need to Know
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

CPAP machines and other assisted-sleeping devices are permitted at Hostel Brikette, but only in private rooms.

**Why private rooms only**

   - Devices that create continuous or intermittent sound — including CPAP machines, white-noise generators, meditation speakers, and talking clocks — are not permitted in shared dorms
   - This policy protects the sleep environment for all dorm guests

**What to do**

   - Book a private room for your stay
   - Email us before arrival to let us know you will be bringing a device so we can confirm the room setup

Full accessibility information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/age-accessibility>

subject: Medication Refrigeration — Arrangements and Nearby Services
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

If you are travelling with medication that requires refrigeration, we can usually arrange storage for you.

**What to do**

   - Email us before your arrival to reserve space — we cannot guarantee availability if it is not arranged in advance
   - Label your medication clearly with your name and room or bed number when you arrive

**Nearby pharmacy and medical services**

   - Farmacia Positano is approximately 450 m away on Viale Pasitea — the closest pharmacy for prescriptions and supplies
   - A public medical clinic is in Praiano (~3 km by bus)
   - In an emergency, staff will contact Italian emergency services (112 / 118)
   - We cannot provide professional medical assistance on site

Full accessibility information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/age-accessibility>

subject: Minors Policy — Age Requirements for Booking
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Our policy on minors complies with Italian hospitality regulations. Please read this before booking.

**Ages 16 and under**

   - Private rooms only — dorm beds are not available
   - Must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian aged 18 or over
   - The guardian must stay in the same room for the entire stay

**Age 17**

   - A dorm bed may be possible with a supervising adult (18+) in the same dorm
   - Appropriate consent or guardianship documentation must be presented at arrival
   - Email us in advance to confirm what documentation is needed for your situation

**Groups under 18 (school, sports, scouts)**

   - Exclusive occupancy must be arranged before the stay
   - Written responsibility documentation from the organising institution is required at least 7 days before arrival

**Important**

   - Minors cannot be left unattended in common areas
   - If requirements are not met at check-in, we may be legally required to refuse the stay

Full age and accessibility information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/age-accessibility>

subject: What to Expect at Hostel Brikette — Pre-Arrival Overview
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

A few things to know before you arrive so you can plan ahead.

**Stairs are unavoidable**

   - There are approximately 30 outdoor stone steps from the nearest lane to reception
   - Most dorms are 1–2 additional internal flights above reception
   - There is no lift and no step-free access — Brikette is in a historic hillside building

**Pack light and plan your luggage**

   - A backpack is much easier than a large wheeled suitcase on Positano's stairs and lanes
   - If you are arriving by ferry with heavy luggage, a porter combined with the local Interno bus is the recommended approach
   - Wear shoes with good grip — stone steps can be slippery, especially if wet

**If mobility is a concern**

   - Email us before booking and we will describe the exact layout and walking routes in detail
   - We want you to be able to make an informed decision

**Arriving late**

   - Message us your estimated arrival time so we can plan check-in

Full accessibility and arrival information:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/age-accessibility>

subject: Digital Concierge — How to Get Same-Day Recommendations
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

The digital concierge is the quickest way to get same-day recommendations from the team — especially useful when plans change or ferries are cancelled.

**How to access it**

   - Ask reception for the latest contact details or QR code — the channel is usually WhatsApp

**What to include in your message**

   - Your dates and starting point
   - The time window you have available
   - Budget per person
   - Your number one priority

**Example message you can copy**

"We have 6 hours, no car. We want (A) a swim and (B) sunset. Budget €40 per person. What is the simplest plan and the backup if ferries are cancelled?"

**Good for**

   - Same-day logistics when ferries or transport options change
   - Local recommendations matched to your time window and budget
   - Help booking experiences or arranging transport on the Amalfi Coast

Digital concierge guide:
<https://hostel-positano.com/en/guides/digital-concierge-service>

subject: Private Transfer to Positano — Booking Through Reception
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

A private transfer is the most comfortable way to travel between the airports, Naples, and Positano. We work with a recommended driver who covers these routes.

**Estimated cost**

   - Airport to/from Positano: approx. €130 per vehicle

Prices are per vehicle (not per person) and are confirmed directly with the driver.

**How to book**

   - Contact reception and we will connect you with our recommended driver via WhatsApp
   - Have your travel date, time, pickup point, and number of passengers ready
   - Confirm the fare directly with the driver before proceeding

For current rates on other routes (Naples Centrale, Salerno, Sorrento), please ask reception.

subject: Breakfast — What We Offer and How to Order

subject: Modifying or Cancelling a Booking.com / Agoda Reservation
body:
{{SLOT:GREETING}}

Because your booking was made through a third-party platform (such as Booking.com or Agoda), modifications and cancellations need to go through them directly. The transaction is handled by the platform, not by us, which means we have less flexibility to make changes on our side.

**What this means in practice**

   - Cancellations and refund requests must be submitted through the OTA's platform
   - Date changes typically require cancelling and rebooking through the same platform
   - We cannot override the cancellation policy applied at the time of booking

**If you want more flexibility in future**

Booking directly through our website gives you faster responses and, in some cases, more options for changes.

If you need help navigating the process, share your booking reference and we will do what we can.
